title: 115_s2130
content: The "Outdoor Economy Act" is the short title of the Act. It establishes an Outdoor Recreation Advisory Committee. The "Outdoor Recreation Advisory Committee" is established within the Department of the Interior with 17 members including key officials from various agencies such as the Forest Service, Fish and Wildlife Service, Bureau of Land Management, National Park Service, and the Chief of Engineers. The "Outdoor Recreation Advisory Committee" within the Department of the Interior consists of 17 members, including officials from different agencies and representatives from diverse outdoor recreation groups. The Outdoor Recreation Advisory Committee includes members from various outdoor recreation groups such as human-powered transportation organizations, youth outreach and education organizations, veterans service organizations, outdoor recreation retail industry, and conservation organizations. Appointments must be made within 180 days of the Act's enactment, and members serve for a specified term with provisions for vacancies. The Outdoor Recreation Advisory Committee members serve for life, vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, a chairperson and vice chairperson are selected from the members, meetings are called by the chairperson, and the Committee conducts a study on increasing public access to public land. The Outdoor Recreation Advisory Committee focuses on increasing public access to public land, addressing maintenance needs, reducing barriers for underserved communities, promoting service opportunities for youth, engaging the community to combat invasive species, and strengthening the outdoor recreation economy. A report is required within 2 years of the Act's enactment. The Outdoor Recreation Advisory Committee must submit a report to Congress every 2 years with detailed findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation and administrative actions. The Committee has the power to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and take necessary actions to fulfill its duties. The Committee may request necessary information from Federal departments or agencies and use the United States mails. Non-federal members shall be compensated at a daily rate equivalent to the annual basic pay. The Committee members are compensated at a daily rate equivalent to the annual basic pay for their duties, with federal employees serving without additional compensation. Members are also allowed travel expenses at authorized rates. The Committee members are compensated at authorized rates for their duties and travel expenses. The chairperson can appoint an executive director and necessary personnel without following civil service laws. The executive director's employment is subject to confirmation by the Committee. Compensation is provided as per regulations. The chairperson of the Committee has the authority to set the compensation for the executive director and staff without following certain civil service laws. The maximum pay rate for these positions is capped at level V of the Executive Schedule. Temporary and intermittent services can be procured as needed. The chairperson of the Committee can procure temporary and intermittent services at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual pay for level V of the Executive Schedule. $2,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year for this purpose.
